factoid: The commander shouted "How are you standing? Where's your leg? Your leg?"
The commander spoke with a tone of suffering.
There were still five men between the commander and Dólokhov.
Dólokhov wore a bluish-gray uniform.
Dólokhov slowly straightened his bent knee.
Dólokhov looked straight at the general with clear, insolent eyes.
Dólokhov began to say "Why a blue coat? Off with it... Sergeant major! Change his coat... the ras..." but did not finish.
Dólokhov said "General, I must obey orders, but I am not bound to endure..."
Dólokhov hurriedly interrupted.
The commander declared "No talking in the ranks!... No talking, no talking!"
Dólokhov replied "Not bound to endure insults."
The general's eyes met Dólokhov's eyes.
The general became silent and angrily pulled down his tight scarf.
The general requested Dólokhov to change his coat.
The signaler shouted "He's coming!" at that moment.
The regimental commander flushed and ran to his horse.
The regimental commander seized the stirrup with trembling hands.
The regimental commander threw his body across the saddle.
The regimental commander righted himself.
The regimental commander drew his saber.
The regimental commander had a happy and resolute countenance.
The regimental commander opened his mouth awry.
The regimental commander prepared to shout.
The regiment fluttered like a bird preening its plumage and became motionless.
The regimental commander shouted "Attention!" in a soul‑shaking voice.
The regimental commander's voice expressed joy for himself, severity for the regiment, and welcome for the approaching chief.
Along the broad country road edged on both sides by trees came a high light‑blue Viennese calèche.
The calèche was slightly creaking on its springs.
The calèche was drawn by six horses at a smart trot.
Behind the calèche galloped a suite and a convoy of Croats.
Beside Kutúzov sat an Austrian general in a white uniform.
The Austrian general's white uniform looked strange among the Russian black uniforms.
The calèche stopped in front of the regiment.
Kutúzov and the Austrian general were talking in low voices.
Kutúzov smiled slightly as he stepped down from the carriage.
The regiment was breathlessly gazing at Kutúzov and the regimental commander did not exist.
The word of command rang out.
The regiment quivered again.
The regiment presented arms with a jingling sound.
The feeble voice of the commander in chief was heard.
The regiment roared "Health to your ex... len... len... lency!"
The regiment became silent again.
Kutúzov stood still while the regiment moved.
Kutúzov and the general in white, accompanied by the suite, walked between the ranks.
The regimental commander saluted the commander in chief.
The regimental commander devoured the commander in chief with his eyes.
The regimental commander drew himself up obsequiously.
The regimental commander walked through the ranks behind the generals.
The regimental commander bent forward and hardly restrained his jerky movements.
The regimental commander darted forward at every word or gesture of the commander in chief.
The regimental commander performed his duty as a subordinate with greater zeal than his duty as a commander.
Thanks to the strictness and assiduity of its commander, the regiment was in splendid condition compared with others that had reached Braunau at the same time.
There were only 217 sick and stragglers in the regiment.
Everything was in good order except the boots.
